subject: Re: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: So said  Curt Sampson  on  2/10/2003 -------------------- ...  ... SQL ... master ... projects. If I change the SQL statements, then I test the new
messageBody:
So said Curt Sampson on 2/10/2003 --------------------

>On Sun, 9 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

<snip />

>> If I don't change the DBMS nor the operating environment, then the
SQL
>> statements, once correct, cannot break. They become a "golden
master"
>> against which I can continue to compare as needed.
>
>Well, true...but how you get away with not changing the SQL for long
>periods is beyond me. I've never done serious develoment on a system
>with a lot of database code where the database wasn't changing all the
>time. But we probably just tend to work on different styles of
projects.

If I change the SQL statements, then I test the new statements as
needed. That's why I put them in one place, to make them easier to test
all at once and in isolation from the rest of the system.

>> Better would be to have some in-memory SQL syntax/semantics checker
>> that worked against my database schema, simulated the statements and
>> ensured that they continue to make sense.
>
>No, this to my mind would be a complete waste of time. If you haven't
>changed the statements, you don't need to syntax check them, even, as
>you pointed out. Just return the data the statement is supposed to
return
>and leave it at that.
>
>If you do change the statements, and you're not checking them against
>the database, you're going to need an *extremely* thorough and
accurate
>simulation of the database software. Given the huge complexity of
quirks
>of most RDBMSs, that would be extraordinally expensive and difficult.
>Why not just use the most accurate simulation, the database itself?

Indeed, but I don't want to run tests against the database all the
time. That's all.

>> But like I said, if I move all the SQL statements into one place, I
can
>> easily write a simple test to verify those statements against the
>> database. I can run that test less frequently, thus avoiding the
>> overhead of running them all the time.
>
>There is no need to have all your statements separated from the code
that
>uses them in order to test separately. I'm sure you can come up with
many
>other ways to turn on and off individual tests.

I have found turning tests on and off to be more harm than good.
Perhaps I've just never done it well.
